subject: Critical Thinking
title: Fallacies in Advertising: How Brands Trick Your Brain
description: A fast breakdown of Fallacies in Advertising: How Brands Trick Your Brain for builders.

hook.text: '9 out of 10 dentists recommend...' Recommend what? Over what? Who funded the study?

buildup.text: Ads use bandwagon, appeal to authority, and false dilemma.

discovery.text: Weasel words do the heavy lifting: 'helps fight,' 'up to 50% off,' 'part of a balanced diet.' Technically true.

twist.text: Advertisers don't need you to believe the claim ‚Äî just to remember the brand. The fallacy creates the memory.

climax.text: Advertising spending exceeds $700 billion/year globally. It wouldn't exist if fallacious persuasion didn't work.

punchline.text: If the logic doesn't hold up, the jingle still will.

quiz.question: What are 'weasel words' in advertising?
options: Technically true phrases that imply more than they prove
Words that sound like animal names
